content.description: Layback on the leftmost flake of Animals, and follow it straight about 2/3's the way to the top. Reach out to the left for a nice knob and transfer over to the top of Dark Side of the Moon.
content.protection: There are new TR anchors as of the Fall of 2011.
content.location: This is just right of the tree in the center of Pink Floyd Wall.

content.description:
Make reachy moves on thin edges to a sort of cool stemming crux (using the left side of the Dark Side Flake).   

  This may be the only true face climb at the otherwise slabby Redrock.
content.protection: 3 bolts to TR anchors at the top.  The anchors are set back from the main face, so this requires long slings to set up properly.
content.location: The Pink Floyd Wall is the first (small) wall one comes to on the approach to the main cliff. This climb ascends up the face on the left of the prominent Dark Side flake.

content.description: This chimney problem is short but sweet. It is slightly overhanging. Use the corner crack and rock features to topout.
content.location: This is the leftmost problem of Pink Floyd. It is a little tucked away, but just follow the wall south to the highway. You will see this no more than 50 feet from the highway.

content.description: The hardest part of this climb is actually just getting to the crack. Then just go straight up.
content.protection: This route has good placements. The crack is never wider than a #1 BD Camalot. Two pieces seem like all you need.
content.location: This is the crack on the left end of Pink Floyd Wall between Atom Heart Mother and the Unnamed Bolted Face .

content.description:
Start well left under the bolted face and climb up and to the right on a couple of thin edges to base of flake, then undercling and layback the flake to the top.  The crux is probably getting fully onto the flake.   

  The flake is a cool feature that offers moves reminiscent of other (taller and better) climbs.
content.protection:
Bolted TR anchors.   

  I thought I remember this flake expanding a bit (a long time ago), but it felt pretty solid the last time I climbed it.  It could be led, but you would have to place gear semi-blind and would be pretty strenuous.  It would be good practice though for harder climbs maybe, but it is a fun top-rope.
content.location: The Pink Floyd Wall is the first (small) wall one comes to on the approach to the main cliff.  The climb ascends up and around the flake that is probably the most prominent feature on the cliff.

content.description: This is the bolted arete on the left end of Pink Floyd Wall. Start on the stump at the bottom and follow it straight up the corner.
content.protection: Two bolts, no TR anchors directly above. Bring extra slings to setup up either on a near by tree or the TR anchors of other routes.
content.location: This is the left arete of the Pink Floyd Wall.

content.description: This is the entire right half of the Pink Floyd Wall. There are numerous variations on this section. Pretty much all the variations involve a nice layback to the top.
content.protection: There are TR anchors as of the Fall of 2011 or anchor off the tree up top. A few variations could be lead here, using a standard rack
content.location: This is the right end of the Pink Floyd Wall.

content.description:
This is a steep, short crag that offers only a few, but nonetheless, great climbs. Pink Floyd Wall offers trad and sport lines, along with new TR anchors with rings in 2011. It is East-facing with sun in the morning to afternoon. 

  L->R: 

  A. Ummagumma, V0+, 8'.   B. Atom Heart Mother, 6, 1p, 20', bolts or TR.   C. Meddle, 6, 1p, 20', TR or gear.   D1. Unnamed Bolted Face , ~10, 1p, 30', bolts.   D2. Dark Side of the Moon , 10-, 1p, 30', TR.   E. Wish You Were Here, 7, 1p, 20', TR.   F. Animals, 5, 1p, 20', TR. 

  Just to the northwest is the Main Crag of Redrock.
